For Legendre associated functions of the first and second kinds

prevtext:
\title{BCOV rings on elliptic curves and Eta function}
   \author{So Okada}

   \address{National Institute of Technology, Oyama College. Tochigi, Japan
   323-0806}

   \email{okada@oyama-ct.ac.jp}

   \maketitle

   \begin{abstract} 
     Associated Legendre functions of the first kind give a family of
     BCOV rings on elliptic curves.  We prove that the family is
     parametrized by $q$-exponents of the eta function $\eta(q^{24})$.
     Our method involves a classification of rational solutions of a
     Riccati equation under some constraints.
  \end{abstract}

  \section{Introduction}\label{sec:first-intro}
  In this paper, we parametrize a family of BCOV rings on elliptic
  curves by the eta function.  As such, this paper can be seen as a
  step forward on understanding meromorphic ambiguity on BCOV theory
  \cite{BCOV} by a modular form.

  BCOV rings \cite{Hos} have been introduced to study {\it BCOV
    holomorphic anomaly equations} of Bershadsky, Cecotti, Ooguri and
  Vafa \cite{BCOV}.  BCOV theory has gained much interest in
  mathematics and physics \cite{YamYau,Ali,AliLan,KanZho}.

  A major challenge of BCOV theory is meromorphic ambiguity to compute
  Gromov-Witten potentials.  For this, let us take $\Gamma=\langle
  \left(\begin{smallmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ -1 & 1
    \end{smallmatrix}\right),
  \left(\begin{smallmatrix}
      1 & 1 \\
      0 & 1
    \end{smallmatrix}\right) \rangle\subset {\operatorname{SL}}_{2}({\mathbb Z})$
  and recall a finitely-generated $\Gamma$-invariant BCOV ring
  ${\mathcal R}_{BCOV}^{\Gamma}$ on elliptic curves.  This ring is
  fundamental in BCOV rings.  To define each ${\mathcal
    R}_{BCOV}^{\Gamma}$, we need to choose $r(x)\in {\mathbb C}(x)$ that
  solves the following Riccati equation. This choice corresponds to
  the meromorphic ambiguity of the BCOV theory. For $x\in {\mathbb P}^{1}$,
  $\lambda\in {\mathbb Q}$, and the {\it Griffith-Yukawa coupling}
  $C_{x}=\frac{1}{(1-432 x)x}$, there is the Riccati equation:

For Legendre associated functions of the first and second kinds
  $P_{\alpha}^{\beta}(x)$ and $Q_{\alpha}^{\beta}(x)$ and $C\in
  {\mathbb P}^{1}$, Equation \ref{eq:Hosono-Riccati} admits the general
  solution:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{1}{12}\left(5+4320x+(-5+12\sqrt{\lambda})\frac{CP_{\frac{5%
}{6}}^{2\sqrt{\lambda}}(-1+864x)+Q_{\frac{5}{6}}^{2\sqrt{\lambda}}(-1+864x)}{%
CP_{-\frac{1}{6}}^{2\sqrt{\lambda}}(-1+864x)+Q_{-\frac{1}{6}}^{2\sqrt{\lambda}%
}(-1+864x)}\right)." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>4320</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mi>λ</mi></msqrt></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>P</mi><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mi>λ</mi></msqrt></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>864</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>Q</mi><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mi>λ</mi></msqrt></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>864</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mi>λ</mi></msqrt></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>864</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>Q</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mi>λ</mi></msqrt></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>864</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Let $R_{\infty}$ be the family of ${\mathcal
    R}_{BCOV}^{\Gamma}$ for all $r(x,\lambda)\in {\mathbb C}(x)$.  Let
  $\chi(n)$ be the Dirichlet character of mod 12 such that $\chi(\pm
  1)=1$ and $\chi(\pm 5)=-1$.  We prove the following.
  \begin{theorem}\label{thm}
    The family $R_{\infty}$ of finitely-generated
    $\Gamma$-invariant BCOV rings on elliptic curves 
    is parametrized
    by the $q$-exponents of the eta function
    $\eta(q^{24})=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \chi(n) q^{n^2}= q - q^{25} -
    q^{49} + q^{121} + q^{169}\cdots$. Namely, $r(x,\lambda)\in
    {\mathbb C}(x)$ if and only if $144\lambda=1, 25, 49, 121, 169, \cdots$,
    squares of numbers prime to $6$.
  \end{theorem}

  \section{Proofs}
  To study when $r(x,\lambda)\in {\mathbb C}(x)$, let us first consider
  $r(x,\lambda)$ at a fixed singularity of Equation
  \ref{eq:Hosono-Riccati}.

  \begin{lemma}\label{lem:numbers}
    If $r(x,\lambda)\in {\mathbb C}(x)$, then
    $144\lambda=1, 25, 49,
    121, 169, \cdots$.
  \end{lemma}
  \begin{proof}
    At $x=\infty$, unless $\frac{5}{6}-2\sqrt{\lambda}\in {\mathbb Z}_{\leq
      0}$, the Lawrent expansion of $r(x,\lambda)$ is

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{1}{12}\left(-5+4320x+(-5+12\sqrt{\lambda})\frac{P_{\frac{5%
}{6}}^{2\sqrt{\lambda}}(-1+864x)}{P_{-\frac{1}{6}}^{2\sqrt{\lambda}}(-1+864x)}%
\right)." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>4320</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mi>λ</mi></msqrt></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><msubsup><mi>P</mi><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mi>λ</mi></msqrt></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>864</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mi>λ</mi></msqrt></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>864</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

Since
    $r(x,\lambda)\in {\mathbb C}(x)$,
    $\frac{1}{\Gamma(\frac{1}{6}-2\sqrt{\lambda})}$ has to
    vanish. Thus, $\frac{1}{6}-2\sqrt{\lambda}\in {\mathbb Z}_{\leq 0}$.
  \end{proof}

{2}}F(n,m,x)+(n-m)(n+m+1)(1-x^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}})" display="inline"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><msubsup><mi>P</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>m</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>P</mi><mi>n</mi><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>m</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>m</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>m</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></msup></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Thus, the lemma holds.
\end{proof}

Let us prove Theorem \ref{thm}.

\begin{proof}
  We confirm the converse of Lemma \ref{lem:numbers}.  Since
  $f(-\frac{1}{6},\frac{1}{6},x)=x$,
  $r(x,\frac{1}{144})=-\frac{1}{12}+72x\in {\mathbb C}(x)$. Thus, by Lemma
  \ref{lem:induction}, $r(x,\frac{i^2}{144})\in {\mathbb C}(x)$ for
  $i=1,7,13,\cdots$.  If $\lambda=\frac{5^2}{144}$, since $-5+12
  \sqrt{\lambda}=0$, $r(x,\lambda)=-\frac{5}{12} + 360 x\in {\mathbb C}(x)$.
  For $\lambda=\frac{i^2}{144}$ of $i=11,17,23,\cdots$,
  $f(-\frac{1}{6},\frac{11}{6},x)=\frac{1}{x}$ implies
  $r(x,\lambda)\in {\mathbb C}(x)$ by Lemma \ref{lem:induction}.  Thus, the
  assertion holds.
\end{proof}

\begin{remark}
  By Lemma \ref{lem:numbers}, we do not have to assume $\lambda\in
  {\mathbb Q}$ to define ${\mathcal R}_{BCOV}^{\Gamma}$ for $r(x,\lambda)$.
  By the proof of the theorem and Lemma \ref{lem:induction}, we
  observe that $r(x,\lambda)\in {\mathbb C}(x)$ implies $r(x,\lambda)\in
  {\mathbb Q}(x)$.  Lemma \ref{lem:induction} holds for associated Legendre
  functions of the second kind. But, $r(x,\frac{1}{144},C)\not\in
  {\mathbb C}(x)$ unless $C\to \infty$, since the Lawrent expansion of
  $r(x,\frac{1}{144},C)$ at $x=\infty$ is $72 x+\frac{4
    (-2)^{\frac{2}{3}}\Gamma(-\frac{4}{3})\Gamma(\frac{5}{6})}{\sqrt{3
      \pi } (2 i
    C+\pi)}x^{\frac{1}{3}}-\frac{1}{12}+O\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)^{\frac{1}{4}}$.
\end{remark}

their helpful communications.
